awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 New England Hardware Security Day (NEHWS2023)
awd_abstract_narration:
Hardware security is a topic of increasing concern in the cybersecurity field for scientific and national security reasons.

This workshop sponsors students to participate in the 2023 New England Hardware Security Day (NEHWS2023) held in April 2023. The workshop is a venue for researchers and practitioners in hardware security to present the latest research, and to explore opportunities for future research.  By including representatives from academia and industry around New England, the event will provide students insight into a range of perspectives, as well as potential post-university employment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The New England Hardware Security Day (NEHWS 2023) was held as a 1-day workshop on April 7, 2023 at Northeastern University, Egan Research Center. The workshop had a total attendance of 139, out of which 58 were non-student/industry attendees, 81 were students. This NSF travel grant has been used in supporting student attendance at the workshop. The workshop featured 24 student-presented posters in the poster competition, and a lineup of keynote talks, long and short paper presentations, a panel, and a poster session. 

Kevin Fu gave a keynote talk on "Wicked bizarre semiconductor physics of sensor security." Ran Canetti gave a keynote talk on "From NAND to SCOTUS". The panel discussed "Security of Hardware Systems in a Zero-trust Model" and featured the distinguished panelists Lei Poo from Analog Devices, Dan Walters from MITRE, Hamed Okhravi from MIT Lincoln Lab, Sandhya Koteshwara from IBM, and Sina Shahbazmohamadi from the University of Connecticut. There were 25 posters selected for a competition, out which 5 posters are selected as the winners. Each student presenter was awarded corresponding hardware security setup and/or textbooks. 


The event was jointly organized by researchers from Northeastern University, UMass Amherst, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, and Yale. The organizing committee was from different New England universities, and they are Yarkin Doroz, Yunsi Fei, Fatemeh Ganji, Daniel Holcomb, Koksal Mus, Patrick Schaumont, Berk Sunar, Jakub Szefer, Shahin Tajik, Xiaolin Xu, Mengjia Yan, Qiaoyan Yu. The event has significantly helped to strengthen bonds within the New England hardware security community, and exposed students to state-of-the-art research topics in a field of major importance to our region.


Last Modified: 03/30/2024
Modified by: Xiaolin Xu
